- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

```console
PS> $env:myvar1 = $false
PS> !$env:myvar1
False
PS> -not $env:myvar1
False
PS> $env:myvar1 -eq $false
True
```

### Expected behavior

It should work like for non-environment variables:
```console
PS> $myvar2 = $false
PS> !$myvar2
True
PS> -not $myvar2
True
```


### Actual behavior

Boolean environment variable is not negatable

comments.body: Environment variables are OS feature and are simple strings - no strong types exist.

comments.author: jborean93
comments.body: Adding to the above the behaviour you are seeing is how the boolean is being casted to a string. PowerShell is essentially doing `[string]$false` which becomes `False` as a string when you set the value. When you do `-not "False"` or `!"False"` the output is `$False` because the string value is not equal to `$False` when you cast it to to a bool. `$env:myvar1 -eq $false` is `$true` because it will cast the RHS to a string then compare.

title: Boolean environment variable is not negatable
